scene.stagedir: Enter the Duke of Epheſus, with the Merchant of Siracuſa, Iaylor, and other attendants

speech.speaker: Marchant.
speech.line: Proceed Solinus to procure my fall,
And by the doome of death end wœs and all.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Merchant of Siracuſa, plead no more.
I am not partiall to infringe our Lawes;
The enmity and diſcord which of late
Sprung from the rancorous outrage of your Duke,
To Merchants our well-dealing Countrimen,
Who wanting gilders to redeeme their liues,
Haue ſeal’d his rigorous ſtatutes with their blouds,
Excludes all pitty from our threatning lookes:
For ſince the mortall and inteſtine iarres
Twixt thy ſeditious Countrimen and vs ,
It hath in ſolemne Synodes beene decreed,
Both by the Siracuſians and our ſelues,
To admit no trafficke to our aduerſe townes:
Nay more, if any borne at Epheſus
Be ſeene at any Siracuſian Marts and Fayres:
Againe, if any Siracuſian borne
Come to the Bay of Epheſus, he dies:
His goods confiſcate to the Dukes diſpoſe,
Vnleſſe a thouſand markes be leuied
To quit the penalty, and to ranſome him:
Thy ſubſtance, valued at the higheſt rate,
Cannot amount vnto a hundred Markes,
Therefore by Law thou art condemn’d to die.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Yet this my comfort, when your words are done,
My wœs end likewiſe with the euening Sonne.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Well Siracuſian; ſay in briefe the cauſe
Why thou departedſt from thy natiue home?
And for what cauſe thou cam’ſt to Epheſus.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: A heauier taske could not haue beene impos’d,
Then I to ſpeake my griefes vnſpeakeable:
Yet that the world may witneſſe that my end
Was wrought by nature, not by vile offence,
Ile vtter what my ſorrow giues me leaue.
In Syracuſa was I borne, and wedde
Vnto a woman, happy but for me,
And by me; had not our hap beene bad:
With her I liu’d in ioy, our wealth increaſt
By proſperous voyages I often made
To Epidamium, till my faƈtors death,
And he great care of goods at randone left,
Drew me from kinde embracements of my ſpouſe;
From whom my abſence was not ſixe moneths olde,
Before her ſelfe (almoſt at fainting vnder
The pleaſing puniſhment that women beare)
Had made prouiſion for her following me,
And ſoone, and ſafe, arriued where I was:
There had ſhe not beene long, but ſhe became
A ioyfull mother of two goodly ſonnes:
And, which was ſtrange, the one ſo like the other,
As could not be distinguiſh’d but by names.
That very howre, and in the ſelfe-ſame Inne,
A meane woman was deliuered
Of ſuch a burthen Male, twins both alike:
Thoſe, for their parents were exceeding poore,
I bought, and brought vp to attend my ſonnes.
My wife, not meanely prowd of two ſuch boyes,
Made daily motions for our home returne:
Vnwilling I agreed, alas, too ſoone wee came aboord.
A league from Epidamium had we ſaild
Before the alwaies winde-obeying deepe
Gaue any Tragicke Inſtance of our harme:
But longer did we not retaine much hope;
For what obſcured light the heauens did grant,
Did but conuay vnto our fearefull mindes
A doubtfull warrant of immediate death,
Which though my ſelfe would gladly haue imbrac’d,
Yet the inceſſant weepings of my wife,
Weeping before for what ſhe ſaw muſt come,
And pitteous playnings of the prettie babes
That mourn’d for faſhion, ignorant what to feare,
Forſt me to ſeeke delayes for them and me,
And this it was: (for other meanes was none)
The Sailors ſought for ſafety by our boate,
And left the ſhip then ſinking ripe to vs.
My wife, more carefull for the latter borne,
Had faſtned him vnto a ſmall ſpare Maſt,
Such as ſea-faring men prouide for ſtormes:
To him one of the other twins was bound,
Whil’ſt I had beene like heedfull of the other.
The children thus diſpos’d, my wife and I,
Fixing our eyes on whom our care was fixt,
Faſtned our ſelues at eyther end the maſt,
And floating ſtraight, obedient to the ſtreame,
Was carried towards Corinth, as we thought.
At length the ſonne gazing vpon the earth,
Diſperſt thoſe vapours that offended vs,
And by the benefit of his wiſhed light
The ſeas waxt calme, and we diſcouered
Two ſhippes from farre, making amaine to vs:
Of Corinth that, of Epidarm this,
But ere they came, oh let me ſay no more,
Gather the ſequell by that went before.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Nay forward old man, dœ not breake off ſo,
For we may pitty, though not pardon thee.

speech.speaker: Merch.
speech.line: Oh had the gods done ſo, I had not now
Worthily tearm’d them mercileſſe to vs:
For ere the ſhips could meet by twice fiue leagues,
We were encountred by a mighty rocke,
Which being violently borne vp,
Our helpefull ſhip was ſplitted in the midſt;
So that in this vniuſt diuorce of vs,
Fortune had left to both of vs alike,
What to delight in, what to ſorrow for,
Her part, poore ſoule, ſeeming as burdened
With leſſer waight, but not with leſſer wœ,
Was carried with more ſpeed before the winde,
And in our ſight they three were taken vp
By Fiſhermen of Corinth, as we thought.
At length another ſhip had ſeiz’d on vs,
And knowing whom it was their hap to ſaue,
Gaue healthfull welcome to their ſhip-wrackt gueſts,
And would haue reft the Fiſhers of their prey,
Had not their backe beene very ſlow of ſaile;
And therefore homeward did they bend their courſe.
Thus haue you heard me ſeuer’d from my bliſſe,
That by misfortunes was my life prolong’d,
To tell ſad ſtories of my owne miſhaps.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: And for the ſake of them thou ſorroweſt for,
Dœ me the fauour to dilate at full,
What haue befalne of them and they till now.

speech.speaker: Merch.
speech.line: My yongeſt boy, and yet my eldeſt care,
At eighteene yeeres became inquiſitiue
After his brother; and importun’d me
That his attendant, ſo his caſe was like,
Reft of his brother, but retain’d his name,
Might beare him company in the queſt of him:
Whom whil’ſt I laboured of a loue to ſee,
I hazarded the loſſe of whom I lou’d.
Fiue Sommers haue I ſpent in fartheſt Greece,
Roming cleane through the bounds of Aſia,
And coaſting homeward, came to Epheſus:
Hopeleſſe to finde, yet loth to leaue vnſought
Or that, or any place that harbours men:
But heere muſt end the ſtory of my life,
And happy were I in my timelie death,
Could all my trauells warrant me they liue.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Hapleſſe Egeon whom the fates haue markt
To beare the extremitie of dire miſhap:
Now truſt me, were it not againſt our Lawes,
Againſt my Crowne, my oath, my dignity,
Which Princes would they may not diſanull,
My ſoule ſhould ſue as aduocate for thee:
But though thou art adiudged to the death,
And paſſed ſentence may not be recal’d
But to our honours great diſparagement:
Yet will I fauour thee in what I can;
Therefore Marchant, Ile limit thee this day
To ſeeke thy helpe by beneficiall helpe,
Try all the friends thou haſt in Epheſus,
Beg thou, or borrow, to make vp the ſumme,
And liue: if no, then thou art doom’d to die:
Iaylor, take him to thy cuſtodie.

speech.speaker: Iaylor.
speech.line: I will my Lord.

speech.speaker: Merch.
speech.line: Hopeleſſe and helpeleſſe doth Egean wend,
But to procraſtinate his liueleſſe end.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholis Erotes, a Marchant, and Dromio.

speech.speaker: Mer.
speech.line: Therefore giue out you are of Epidamium,
Leſt that your goods too ſoone be confiſcate:
This very day a Syracuſian Marchant
Is apprehended for a riuall here,
And not being able to buy out his life,
According to the ſtatute of the towne,
Dies ere the wearie ſunne ſet in the Weſt:
There is your monie that I had to keepe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Gœ beare it to the Centaure, where we hoſt,
And ſtay there Dromio, till I come to thee;
Within this houre it will be dinner time,
Till that Ile view the manners of the towne,
Peruſe the traders, gaze vpon the buildings,
And then returne and ſleepe within mine Inne,
For with long trauaile I am ſtiffe and wearie.
Get thee away.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Many a man would take you at your word,
And gœ indeede, hauing ſo good a meane.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: A truſtie villaine ſir, that very oft,
When I am dull with care and melancholly,
Lightens my humour with his merry ieſts:
What will you walke with me about the towne,
And then gœ to my Inne and dine with me?

speech.speaker: E.Mar.
speech.line: I am inuited ſir to certaine Marchants,
Of whom I hope to make much benefit:
I craue your pardon, ſoone at fiue a clocke,
Pleaſe you, Ile meete with you vpon the Mart,
And afterward conſort you till bed time:
My preſent busineſſe cals me from you now.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Farewell till then: I will gœ looſe my ſelfe,
And wander vp and downe to view the Citie.

speech.speaker: E.Mar.
speech.line: Sir, I commend you to your owne content.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: He that commends me to mine owne content,
Commends me to the thing I cannot get:
I to the world am like a drop of water,
That in the Ocean ſeekes another drop,
Who falling there to finde his fellow forth,
(Vnseene, inquiſitiue) confounds himſelfe.
So I, to finde a Mother and a Brother,
In queſt of them (vnhappie a) looſe my ſelfe.
Here comes the almanacke of my true date:
What now? How chance thou art return’d ſo ſoone.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Return’d ſo ſoone, rather approacht too late:
The Capon burnes, the Pig fals from the ſpit;
The clocke hath ſtrucken twelue vpon the bell:
My Miſtris made it one vpon my cheeke:
She is ſo hot becauſe the meate is colde:
The meate is colde, becauſe you come not home:
You come not home, becauſe you haue no ſtomacke:
You haue no ſtomacke, hauing broke your faſt:
But we that know what ’tis to faſt and pray,
Are penitent for your default to day.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Stop in your winde ſir, tell me this I pray?
Where haue you left the mony that I gaue you.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Oh ſixe pence that I had a wenſday laſt,
To pay the Sadler for my Miſtris crupper:
The Sadler had it Sir, I kept it not.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I am not in a ſportiue humor now:
Tell me, and dally not, where is the monie?
We being ſtrangers here, how dar’ſt thou truſt
So great a charge from thine owne cuſtodie.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: I pray you ieſt ſir as you ſit at dinner:
I from my Miſtris come to you in poſt:
If I returne I ſhall be poſt indeede.
For ſhe will ſcoure your fault vpon my pate:
Me thinkes your maw, like mine, ſhould be your cooke,
And ſtrike you home without a meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come Dromio, come, theſe ieſts are out of ſeaſon,
Reſerue them till a merrier houre then this:
Where is the gold I gaue in charge to thee?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: To me ſir? why you gaue no gold to me?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come on ſir knaue, haue done your fooliſhnes,
And tell me how thou haſt diſpos’d thy charge.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: My charge was but to fetch you frō the Mart
Home to your houſe, the Phœnix ſir, to dinner;
My Miſtris and her ſiſter ſtaies for you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Now as I am a Chriſtian anſwer me,
In what ſafe place you haue beſtow’d my monie;
Or I ſhall breake that merrie ſconce of yours
That ſtands on tricks, when I am vndiſpos’d:
Where is the thouſand Markes thou hadſt of me?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: I haue ſome markes of yours vpon my pate:
Some of my Miſtris markes vpon my ſhoulders:
But not a thouſand markes betweene you both.
If I ſhould pay your worſhip thoſe againe,
Perchance you will not beare them patiently.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thy Miſtris markes? what Miſtris ſlaue haſt thou?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Your worſhips wife, my Miſtris at the Phœnix;
She that doth faſt till you come home to dinner:
And praies that you will hie you home to dinner.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What wilt thou flout me thus vnto my face
Being forbid? There take you that ſir knaue.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: What meane you ſir, for God ſake hold your hands:
Nay, and you will not ſir, Ile take my heeles.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Vpon my life by ſome deuiſe or other,
The villaine is ore-wrought of all my monie.
They ſay this towne is full of coſenage:
As nimble Iuglers that deceiue the eie:
Darke working Sorcerers that change the minde:
Soule-killing Witches, that deforme the bodie:
Diſguiſed Cheaters, prating Mountebankes;
And manie ſuch like liberties of ſinne:
If it proue ſo, I will be gone the ſooner:
Ile to the Centaur to gœ ſeeke this ſlaue,
I greatly feare my monie is not ſafe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Adriana, wife to Antipholis Sereptus, with Luciana her Siſter

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Neither my husband nor the ſlaue return’d,
That in ſuch haſte I ſent to ſeeke his Maſter?
Sure Luciana it is two a clocke.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Perhaps ſome Merchant hath inuited him,
And from the Mart he’s ſomewhere gone to dinner:
Good Siſter let vs dine, and neuer fret;
A man is Maſter of his libertie:
Time is their Maſter, and when they ſee time,
They’ll gœ or come; if ſo, be patient Siſter.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Why ſhould their libertie then ours be more?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Becauſe their buſineſſe ſtill lies out adore.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Looke when I ſerue him ſo, he takes it thus.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh, know he is the bridle of your will.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: There’s none but aſſes will be bridled ſo.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why, headſtrong liberty is laſht with wœ:
There’s nothing ſituate vnder heauens eye,
But hath his bound in earth, in ſea, in ſkie.
The beaſts, the fiſhes, and the winged fowles
Are their males ſubieƈts, and at their controules:
Man more diuine, the Maſter of all theſe,
Lord of the wide world, and wilde watry ſeas,
Indued with intelleƈtuall ſence and ſoules,
Of more preheminence then fiſh and fowles,
Are maſters to their females, and their Lords:
Then let your will attend on their accords.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: This ſeruitude makes you to keepe vnwed.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Not this, but troubles of the marriage bed.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: But were you wedded, you wold bear ſome ſway

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Ere I learne loue, Ile praƈtiſe to obey.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: How if your husband ſtart ſome other where?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Till he come home againe, I would forbeare.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Patience vnmou’d, no maruel though ſhe pauſe,
They can be meeke, that haue no other cauſe:
A wretched ſoule bruis’d with aduerſitie,
We bid be quiet when we heare it crie.
But were we burdned with like waight of paine,
As much, or more, we ſhould our ſelues complaine:
So thou that haſt no vnkinde mate to greeue thee,
With vrging helpeleſſe patience would releeue me;
But if thou liue to ſee like right bereft,
This foole-beg’d patience in thee will be left.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Well, I will marry one day but to trie:
Heere comes your man, now is your husband nie.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Say, is your tardie maſter now at hand?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Nay, hee’s at too hands with mee, and that my
two eares can witneſſe.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Say, didſt thou ſpeake with him? knowſt thou
his minde?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: I, I, he told his minde vpon mine eare,
Beſhrew his hand, I ſcarce could vnderſtand it.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Spake hee ſo doubtfully, thou couldſt not feele
his meaning.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Nay, hee ſtrooke ſo plainly, I could too well
feele his blowes; and withall ſo doubtfully, that I could
ſcarce vnderſtand them.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: But ſay, I prethee, is he comming home?
It ſeemes he hath great care to pleaſe his wife.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Why Miſtreſſe, ſure my Maſter is horne mad.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: Horne mad, thou villaine?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: I meane not Cuckold mad,
But ſure he is ſtarke mad:
When I deſir’d him to come home to dinner,
He ask’d me for a hundred markes in gold:
’Tis dinner time, quoth I: my gold, quoth he:
Your meat doth burne, quoth I: my gold quoth he:
Will you come, quoth I: my gold, quoth he;
Where is the thouſand markes I gaue thee villaine?
The Pigge quoth I, is burn’d: my gold, quoth he:
My miſtreſſe, ſir, quoth I: hang vp thy Miſtreſſe:
I know not thy miſtreſſe, out on thy miſtreſſe.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Quoth who?

speech.speaker: E.Dr.
speech.line: Quoth my Maſter, I know quoth he, no houſe,
no wife, no mistreſſe: ſo that my arrant due vnto my
tongue, I thanke him, I bare home vpon my ſhoulders:
for in concluſion, he did beat me there.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: Go back againe, thou ſlaue, & fetch him home.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Gœ backe againe, and be new beaten home?
For Gods ſake ſend ſome other meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: Backe ſlaue, or I will breake thy pate a-croſſe.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: And he will bleſſe ý croſſe with other beating:
Betweene you, I ſhall haue a holy head.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: Hence prating peſant, fetch thy Maſter home.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Am I ſo round with you, as you with me,
That like a foot-ball you dœ ſpurne me thus:
You ſpurne me hence, and he will ſpurne me hither,
If I laſt in this ſeruice, you muſt caſe me in leather.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Fie how impatience lowreth in your face.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: His company muſt do his minions grace,
Whil’ſt I at home ſtarue for a merrie looke:
Hath homelie age th’ alluring beauty tooke
From my poore cheeke? then he hath waſted it.
Are my diſcourſes dull? Barren my wit,
If voluble and ſharpe diſcourſe be mar’d,
Vnkindneſſe blunts it more then marble hard.
Dœ their gay veſtments his affeƈtions baite?
That’s not my fault, hee’s maſter of my ſtate.
What ruines are in me that can be found,
By him not ruin’d? Then is he the ground
Of my defeatures. My decayed faire,
A ſunnie looke of his, would ſoone repaire.
But, too vnruly Deere, he breakes the pale,
And feedes from home; poore I am but his ſtale.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Selfe-harming Iealouſie; fie beat it hence.

speech.speaker: Ad.
speech.line: Vnfeeling fools can with ſuch wrongs diſpence:
I know his eye doth homage other-where,
Or elſe, what lets it but he would be here?
Siſter, you know he promis’d me a chaine,
Would that alone, a loue he would detaine,
So he would keepe faire quarter with his bed:
I ſee the Iewell beſt enamaled
Will looſe his beautie: yet the gold bides ſtill
That others touch, and often touching will,
Where gold and no man that hath a name,
By falſhood and corruption doth it ſhame:
Since that my beautie cannot pleaſe his eie,
Ile weepe (what’s left away) and weeping die.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: How manie fond fooles ſerue mad Ielouſie?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The gold I gaue to Dromio is laid vp
Safe at the Centaur, and the heedfull ſlaue
Is wandred forth in care to ſeeke me out
By computation and mine hoſts report.
I could not ſpeake with Dromio, ſince at firſt
I ſent him from the Mart? ſee here he comes.
How now ſir, is your merrie humor alter’d?
As you loue ſtroakes, ſo ieſt with me againe:
You know no Centaur? you receiu’d no gold?
Your Miſtreſſe ſent to haue me home to dinner?
My houſe was at the Phœnix? Waſt thou mad,
That thus ſo madlie thou did didſt anſwere me?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: What anſwer ſir? when ſpake I ſuch a word?

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: Euen now, euen here, not halfe an howre ſince.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I did not ſee you ſince you ſent me hence
Home to the Centaur with the gold you gaue me.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Villaine, thou didſt denie the golds receit,
And toldſt me of a Miſtreſſe, and a dinner,
For which I hope thou feltſt I was diſpleas’d.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee you in this merrie vaine,
What meanes this ieſt, I pray you Maſter tell me?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Yea, doſt thou ieere & flowt me in the teeth?
Thinkſt ý I iest? hold, take thou that, & that.

speech.speaker: S.Dr.
speech.line: Hold ſir, for Gods ſake, now your ieſt is earneſt,
Vpon what bargaine do you giue it me?

speech.speaker: Antiph.
speech.line: Becauſe that I familiarlie ſometimes
Dœ vſe you for my foole, and chat with you,
Your ſawcineſſe will ieſt vpon my loue,
And make a Common of my ſerious howres,
When the ſunne ſhines, let fooliſh gnats make ſport,
But creepe in crannies, when he hides his beames:
If you will ieſt with me, know my aſpeƈt,
And faſhion your demeanor to my lookes,
Or I will beat this method in your ſconce.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Sconce call you it? ſo you would leaue batte-
ring, I had rather haue it a head, and you vſe theſe blows
long, I muſt get a ſconce for my head, and Inſconce it
to, or elſe I ſhall ſeek my wit in my ſhoulders, but I pray
ſir, why am I beaten?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Doſt thou not know?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Nothing ſir, but that I am beaten.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Shall I tell you why?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I ſir, and wherefore; for they ſay, euery why
hath a wherefore.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why firſt for flowting me, and then wherefore,
for vrging it the ſecond time to me.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Was there euer anie man thus beaten out of
ſeason, when in the why and the wherefore, is neither
rime nor reaſon. Well ſir, I thanke you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thanke me ſir, for what?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Marry ſir, for this ſomething that you gaue me
for nothing.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Ile make you amends next, to giue you nothing
for ſomething. But ſay ſir, is it dinner time?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: No ſir, I thinke the meat wants that I haue.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: In good time ſir: what’s that?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Baſting.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well ſir, then ’twill be drie.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: If it be ſir, I pray you eat none of it.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Your reaſon?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Leſt it make you chollericke, and purchaſe me
another drie baſting.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well ſir, learne to ieſt in good time, there’s a
time for all things.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I durſt haue denied that before you were ſo
chollericke.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: By what rule ſir?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Marry ſir, by a rule as plaine as the plaine bald
pate of Father time himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Let’s heare it.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: There’s no time for a man to recouer his haire
that growes bald by nature.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: May he not dœ it by fine and recouerie?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Yes, to pay a fine for a perewig, and recouer
the loſt haire of another man.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why, is Time ſuch a niggard of haire, being (as
it is) ſo plentifull an excrement?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Becauſe it is a bleſſing that hee beſtowes on
beaſts, and what he hath ſcanted them in haire, hee hath
giuen them in wit.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why, but theres manie a man hath more haire
then wit.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Not a man of thoſe but he hath the wit to loſe
his haire.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why thou didſt conclude hairy men plain dea-
lers without wit.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: The plainer dealer, the ſooner loſt; yet he loo-
ſeth it in a kinde of iollitie.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: For what reaſon.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: For two, and ſound ones to.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Nay not ſound I pray you.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Sure ones then.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Nay, not ſure in a thing falſing.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Certaine ones then.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Name them.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: The one to ſaue the money that he ſpends in
trying: the other, that at dinner they ſhould not drop in
his porrage.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: You would all this time haue prou’d, there is no
time for all things.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Marry and did ſir: namely, in no time to re-
couer haire loſt by Nature.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: But your reaſon was not ſubſtantiall, why there
is no time to recouer.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Thus I mend it: Time himſelfe is bald, and
therefore to the worlds end, will haue bald followers.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: I knew ’twould be a bald concluſion: but ſoft,
who wafts vs yonder.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: I, I, Antipholus, looke ſtrange and frowne,
Some other Miſtreſſe hath thy ſweet aſpeƈts:
I am not Adriana, nor thy wife.
The time was once, when thou vn-vrg’d wouldſt vow,
That neuer words were muſicke to thine eare,
That neuer obieƈt pleaſing in thine eye,
That neuer touch well welcome to thy hand,
That neuer meat ſweet-ſauour’d in thy taſte,
Vnleſſe I ſpake, or look’d, or touch’d, or caru’d to thee.
How comes it now, my Husband, oh how comes it,
That thou art then eſtranged from thy ſelfe?
Thy ſelfe I call it, being ſtrange to me:
That vndiuidable Incorporate
Am better then thy deere ſelfes better part.
Ah dœ not teare away thy ſelfe from me;
For know my loue: as eaſie maiſt thou fall
A drop of water in the breaking gulfe,
And take vnmingled thence that drop againe
Without addition or diminiſhing,
As take from me thy ſelfe, and not me too.
How deerely would it touch thee to the quicke,
Shouldſt thou but heare I were licencious?
And that this body conſecrate to thee,
By Ruffian Luſt ſhould be contaminate?
Wouldſt thou not ſpit at me, and ſpurne at me,
And hurle the name of husband in my face,
And teare the ſtain’d ſkin of my Harlot brow,
And from my falſe hand cut the wedding ring,
And breake it with a deepe-diuorcing vow?
I know thou canſt, and therefore ſee thou dœ it.
I am poſſest with an adulterate blot,
My bloud is mingled with the crime of luſt:
For if we two be one, and thou play falſe,
I dœ digeſt the poiſon of thy fleſh,
Being ſtrumpeted by thy contagion:
Keepe then faire league and truce with thy true bed,
I liue diſtain’d, thou vndiſhonoured.

speech.speaker: Antip.
speech.line: Plead you to me faire dame? I know you not:
In Epheſus I am but two houres old,
As ſtrange vnto your towne, as to your talke,
Who euery word by all my wit being ſcan’d,
Wants wit in all, one word to vnderſtand.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: Fie brother, how the world is chang’d with you:
When were you wont to vſe my ſiſter thus?
She ſent for you by Dromio home to dinner.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: By Dromio?

speech.speaker: Drom.
speech.line: By me.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: By thee, and this thou didſt returne from him.
That he did buffet thee, and in his blowes,
Denied my houſe for his, me for his wife.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Did you conuerſe ſir with this gentlewoman:
What is the courſe and drift of your compaƈt?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I ſir? I neuer ſaw her till this time.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Villaine thou lieſt, for euen her verie words,
Didſt thou deliuer to me on the Mart.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I neuer ſpake with her in all my life.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: How can ſhe thus then call vs by our names?
Vnleſſe it be by inſpiration.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: How ill agrees it with your grauitie,
To counterfeit thus groſely with your ſlaue,
Abetting him to thwart me in my moode;
Be it my wrong, you are from me exempt,
But wrong not that wrong with a more contempt.
Come I will faſten on this ſleeue of thine:
Thou art an Elme my husband, I a Vine:
Whoſe weakneſſe married to thy ſtranger ſtate,
Makes me with thy ſtrength to communicate:
If ought poſſeſſe thee from me, it is droſſe,
Vſurping Iuie, Brier, or idle Moſſe,
Who all for want of pruning, with intruſion,
Infeƈt thy ſap, and liue on thy confuſion.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To mee ſhee ſpeakes, ſhee moues mee for her theame;
What, was I married to her in my dreame?
Or ſleepe I now, and thinke I heare all this?
What error driues our eies and eares amiſſe?
Vntill I know this ſure vncertaintie,
Ile entertaine the free’d fallacie.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Dromio, gœ bid the ſeruants ſpred for dinner.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Oh for my beads, I croſſe me for a ſinner.
This is the Fairie land, oh ſpight of ſpights,
We talke with Goblins, Owles and Sprights;
If we obay them not, this will inſue:
They’ll ſucke our breath, or pinch vs blacke and blew.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why prat’ſt thou to thy ſelfe, and anſwer’ſt not?
Dromio, thou Dromio, thou ſnaile, thou ſlug, thou ſot.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I am transformed Maſter, am I not?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I thinke thou art in minde, and ſo am I.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Nay Maſter, both in minde, and in my ſhape.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thou haſt thine owne forme.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: No, I am an Ape.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: If thou art chang’d to ought, ’tis to an Aſſe.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: ’Tis true ſhe rides me, and I long for graſſe.
‘Tis ſo, I am an Aſſe, elſe it could neuer be,
But I ſhould know her as well as ſhe knowes me.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Come, come, no longer will I be a foole,
To put the finger in the eie and weepe;
Whil’ſt man and Maſter laughes my wœs to ſcorne:
Come ſir to dinner, Dromio keepe the gate:
Husband Ile dine aboue with you to day,
And ſhriue you of a thouſand idle prankes:
Sirra, if any aske you for your Maſter,
Say he dines forth, and let no creature enter:
Come ſiſter, Dromio play the Porter well.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Am I in earth, in heauen, or in hell?
Sleeping or waking, mad or well aduiſde:
Knowne vnto theſe, and to my ſelfe diſguiſde:
Ile ſay as they ſay, and perſeuer ſo:
And in this miſt at all aduentures go.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Maſter, ſhall I be Porter at the gate?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I, and let none enter, leaſt I breake your pate.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Come, come, Antipholus, we dine to late.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus of Epheſus, his man Dromio, Angelo the Goldſmith, and Balthaſer the Merchant

speech.speaker: E.Anti.
speech.line: Good ſignior Angelo you muſt excuſe vs all,
My wife is ſhrewiſh when I keepe not howres;
Say that I lingerd with you at your ſhop
To ſee the making of her Carkanet,
And that to morrow you will bring it home.
But here’s a villaine that would face me downe
He met me on the Mart, and that I beat him,
And charg’d him with a thouſand markes in gold,
And that I did denie my wife and houſe;
Thou drunkard thou, what didſt thou meane by this?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Say what you wil ſir, but I know what I know,
That you beat me at the Mart I haue your hand to ſhow;
If ý skin were parchment, & ý blows you gaue were ink,
Your owne hand-writing would tell you what I thinke.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: I thinke thou art an aſſe.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Marry ſo it doth appeare
By the wrongs I ſuffer, and the blowes I beare,
I ſhould kicke being kickt, and being at that paſſe,
You would keepe from my heeles, and beware of an aſſe.

speech.speaker: E.An.
speech.line: Y’are ſad ſignior Balthazar, pray God our cheer
May anſwer my good will, and your good welcom here.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: I hold your dainties cheap ſir, & your welcom deer.

speech.speaker: E.An.
speech.line: Oh ſignior Balthazar, either at fleſh or fiſh,
A table full of welcome, makes ſcarce one dainty diſh.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Good meat ſir is comon that euery churle affords.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: And welcome more common, for thats nothing
but words.

speech.speaker: Bal.
speech.line: Small cheere and great welcome, makes a mer-
rie feaſt.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: I, to a niggardly Hoſt, and more ſparing gueſt:
But though my cates be meane, take them in good part,
Better cheere may you haue, but not with better hart.
But ſoft, my doore is lockt; gœ bid them let vs in.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Maud, Briget, Marian, Ciſley, Gillian, Ginn.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Mome, Malthorſe, Capon, Coxcombe, Idi-
ot, Patch,
Either get thee from the dore, or ſit downe at the hatch:
Doſt thou coniure for wenches, that ý calſt for ſuch ſtore,
When one is one too many, gœ get thee from the dore.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: What patch is made our Porter? my Maſter
ſtayes in the ſtreet.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Let him walke from whence he came, leſt hee
catch cold on’s feet.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: Who talks within there? hoa, open the dore.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Right ſir, Ile tell you when, and you’ll tell
me wherefore.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Wherefore? for my dinner: I haue not din’d to
day.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Nor to day here you muſt not come againe
when you may.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: What art thou that keep’ſt mee out from the
howſe I owe?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: The Porter for this time Sir, and my name is
Dromio.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: O villaine, thou haſt ſtolne both mine office
and my name,
The one nere got me credit, the other mickle blame:
If thou hadſt beene Dromio to day in my place,
Thou wouldſt haue chang’d thy face for a name, or thy
name for an aſſe.

speech.speaker: Luce.
speech.line: What a coile is there Dromio? who are thoſe
at the gate?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Let my Maſter in Luce.

speech.speaker: Luce.
speech.line: Faith no, hee comes too late, and ſo tell your
Maſter.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: O Lord I muſt laugh, haue at you with a Pro-
uerbe,
Shall I ſet in my ſtaffe.

speech.speaker: Luce.
speech.line: Haue at you with another, that’s when? can
you tell?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: If thy name be called Luce, Luce thou haſt an-
ſwer’d him well.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Dœ you heare you minion, you’ll let vs in I
hope?

speech.speaker: Luce.
speech.line: I thought to haue askt you.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: And you ſaid no.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: So come helpe, well ſtrooke, there was blow
for blow.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Thou baggage let me in.

speech.speaker: Luce.
speech.line: Can you tell for whoſe ſake?

speech.speaker: E.Drom.
speech.line: Maſter, knocke the doore hard.

speech.speaker: Luce.
speech.line: Let him knocke till it ake.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: You’ll crie for this minion, if I beat the doore
downe.

speech.speaker: Luce.
speech.line: What needs all that, and a paire of ſtocks in the
towne?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Who is that at the doore ý keeps all this noiſe?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: By my troth your towne is troubled with vn-
ruly boies.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Are you there Wife? you might haue come
before.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: Your wife ſir knaue? go get you from the dore.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: If you went in paine Maſter, this knaue wold
gœ ſore.

speech.speaker: Angelo.
speech.line: Heere is neither cheere ſir, nor welcome, we
would faine haue either.

speech.speaker: Baltz.
speech.line: In debating which was beſt, wee ſhall part
with neither.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: They ſtand at the doore, Maſter, bid them
welcome hither.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: There is ſomething in the winde, that we can-
not get in.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: You would ſay ſo Maſter, if your garments
were thin.
Your cake here is warme within: you ſtand here in the
cold.
It would make a man mad as a Bucke to be ſo bought
and ſold.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Go fetch me ſomething, Ile break ope the gate.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Breake any breaking here, and Ile breake your
knaues pate.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: A man may breake a word with your ſir, and
words are but winde:
I and breake it in your face, ſo he break it not behinde.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: It ſeemes thou want’ſt breaking, out vpon thee
hinde.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Here’s too much out vpon thee, I pray thee let
me in.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I, when fowles haue no feathers, and fiſh haue
no fin.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well, Ile breake in: go borrow me a crow.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: A crow without feather, Maſter meane you ſo;
For a fiſh without a finne, ther’s a fowle without afether,
If a crow help vs in ſirra, wee’ll plucke a crow together.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Go, get thee gon, fetch me an iron Crow.

speech.speaker: Balth.
speech.line: Haue patience ſir, oh let it not be ſo,
Heerein you warre againſt your reputation,
And draw within the compaſſe of ſuſpeƈt
Th’ vnuiolated honor of your wife.
Once this your long experience of your wiſedome,
Her ſober vertue, yeares, and modeſtie,
Plead on your part ſome cauſe to you vnknowne;
And doubt not ſir, but ſhe will well excuſe
Why at this time the dores are made againſt you.
Be rul’d by me, depart in patience,
And let vs to the Tyger all to dinner,
And about euening come your ſelfe alone,
To know the reaſon of this ſtrange reſtraint:
If by ſtrong hand you offer to breake in
Now in the ſtirring paſſage of the day,
A vulgar comment will be made of it;
And that ſuppoſed by the common rowt
Againſt your yet vngalled eſtimation,
That may with foule intruſion enter in,
And dwell vpon your graue when you are dead;
For ſlander liues vpon ſucceſſion:
For euer hows’d, where it gets poſſeſſion.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: You haue preuail’d, I will depart in quiet,
And in deſpight of mirth meane to be merrie:
I know a wench of excellent diſcourſe,
Prettie and wittie; wilde, and yet too gentle;
There will we dine: this woman that I meane
My wife (but I proteſt without deſert)
Hath oftentimes vpbraided me withall:
To her will we to dinner, get you home
And fetch the chaine, by this I know ’tis made,
Bring it I pray you to the Porpentine,
For there’s the houſe: That chaine will I beſtow
(Be it for nothing but to ſpight my wife)
Vpon mine hoſteſſe there, good ſir make haſte:
Since mine owne doores refuſe to entertaine me,
Ile knocke elſe-where, to ſee if they’ll diſdaine me.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Ile meet you at that place ſome houre hence.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Do ſo, this ieſt ſhall cost me ſome expence.

scene.stagedir: Enter Iuliana, with Antipholus of Siracuſia.

speech.speaker: Iulia.
speech.line: And may it be that you haue quite forgot
A husbands office? ſhall Antipholus
Euen in the ſpring of Loue, thy Loue-ſprings rot?
Shall loue in buildings grow ſo ruinate?
If you did wed my ſiſter for her wealth,
Then for her wealths-ſake vſe her with more kindneſſe:
Or if you like elſe-where dœ it by ſtealth,
Muffle your falſe loue with ſome ſhew of blindneſſe:
Let not my ſiſter read it in your eye:
Be not thy tongue thy owne ſhames Orator:
Looke ſweet, ſpeake faire, become diſloyaltie:
Apparell vice like vertues harbenger:
Beare a faire preſence, though your heart be tainted,
Teach ſinne the carriage of a holy Saint,
Be ſecret falſe: what need ſhe be acquainted?
What ſimple thiefe brags of his owne attaine?
’Tis double wrong to truant with your bed,
And let her read it in thy lookes at boord:
Shame hath a baſtard fame, well managed,
Ill deeds is doubled with an euill word:
Alas poore women, make vs not beleeue
(Being compaƈt of credit) that you loue vs,
Though others haue the arme, ſhew vs the ſleeue:
We in your motion turne, and you may moue vs.
Then gentle brother get you in againe;
Comfort my ſiſter, cheere her, call her wiſe;
’Tis holy ſport to be a little vaine,
When the ſweet breath of flatterie conquers ſtrife.

speech.speaker: S.Anti.
speech.line: Sweete Miſtris, what your name is elſe I
know not;
Nor by what wonder you do hit of mine:
Leſſe in your knowledge, and your grace you ſhow not,
Then our earths wonder, more then earth diuine.
Teach me deere creature how to thinke and ſpeake:
Lay open to my earthie groſſe conceit:
Smothred in errors, feeble, ſhallow, weake,
The foulded meaning of your words deceit:
Againſt my ſoules pure truth, why labour you,
To make it wander in an vnknowne field?
Are you a god? would you create me new?
Transforme me then, and to your powre Ile yeeld.
But if that I am I, then well I know,
Your weeping ſiſter is no wife of mine,
Nor to her bed no homage dœ I owe:
Farre more, farre more, to you dœ I decline:
Oh traine me not ſweet Mermaide with thy note,
To drowne me in thy ſiſter floud of teares:
Sing Siren for thy ſelfe, and I will dote:
Spread ore the ſiluer waues thy golden haires;
And as a bud Ile take thee, and there lie:
And in that glorious ſuppoſition thinke,
He gaines by death, that hath ſuch meanes to die:
Let Loue, being light, be drowned if ſhe ſinke.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: What are you mad, that you dœ reaſon ſo?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Not mad, but mated, how I dœ not know.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: It is a fault that ſpringeth from your eie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: For gazing on your beames faire ſun being by.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Gaze when you ſhould, and that will cleere
your ſight.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: As good to winke ſweet loue, as looke on night.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why call you me loue? Call my ſiſter ſo.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thy ſiſters ſiſter.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: That’s my ſiſter.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: No: it is thy ſelfe, mine owne ſelfes better part:
Mine eies cleere eie, my deere hearts deerer heart;
My foode, my fortune, and my ſweet hopes aime;
My ſole earths heauen, and my heauens claime.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: All this my ſiſter is, or elſe ſhould be.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Call thy ſelfe ſiſter ſweet, for I am thee:
Thee will I loue, and with thee lead my life;
Thou haſt no husband yet, nor I no wife:
Giue me thy hand.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh ſoft ſir, hold you ſtill:
Ile fetch my ſiſter to get her good will.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why how now Dromio, where run’ſt thou ſo
faſt?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Dœ you know me ſir? Am I Dromio? Am I
your man? Am I my ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thou art Dromio, thou art my man, thou art
thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: I am an aſſe, I am a womans man, and beſides
my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What womans man? and how beſides thy
ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Marrie ſir, beſides my ſelfe, I am due to a woman:
One that claimes me, one that haunts me, one that will
haue me.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: What claime laies ſhe to thee?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Marry ſir, ſuch claime as you would lay to your
horſe, and ſhe would haue me as a beaſt, not that I bee-
ing a beaſt ſhe would haue me, but that ſhe being a ve-
rie beaſtly creature layes claime to me.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: What is ſhe?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: A very reuerent body: I ſuch a one, as a man
may not ſpeake of, without he ſay ſir reuerence, I haue
but leane lucke in the match, and yet is ſhe a wondrous
fat marriage.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: How doſt thou meane a fat marriage?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Marry ſir, ſhe’s the Kitchin wench, & al greaſe,
and I know not what vſe to put her too, but to make a
Lampe of her, and run from her by her owne light. I
warrant, her ragges and the Tallow in them, will burne
a Poland Winter: If ſhe liues till doomeſday, ſhe’l burne
a weeke longer then the whole World.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: What complexion is ſhe of?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Swart like my ſhoo, but her face nothing like
ſo cleane kept: for why? ſhe ſweats a man may gœ o-
uer-ſhoœs in the grime of it.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: That’s a fault that water will mend.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: No ſir, ’tis in graine, Noahs flood could not
do it.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: What’s her name?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Nell Sir: but her name is three quarters, that’s
an Ell and three quarters, will not meaſure her from hip
to hip.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Then ſhe beares ſome bredth?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: No longer from head to foot, then from hippe
to hippe: ſhe is ſphericall, like a globe: I could find out
Countries in her.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: In what part of her body ſtands Ireland?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Marry ſir in her buttockes, I found it out by
the bogges.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where Scotland?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: I found it by the barrenneſſe, hard in the palme
of the hand.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where France?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: In her forhead, arm’d and reuerted, making
warre againſt her heire.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where England?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: I look’d for the chalkle Cliffes, but I could find
no whiteneſſe in them. But I gueſſe, it ſtood in her chin
by the ſalt rheume that ranne betweene France, and it.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where Spaine?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Faith I ſaw it not: but I felt it hot in her breth.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Where America, the Indies?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Oh ſir, vpon her noſe, all ore embelliſhed with
Rubies, Carbuncles, Saphires, declining their rich Aſ-
peƈt to the hot breath of Spaine, who ſent whole Ar-
madœs of Carreƈts to be ballaſt at her noſe.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Where ſtood Belgia, the Netherlands?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Oh ſir, I did not looke ſo low. To conclude,
this drudge or Diuiner layd claime to mee, call’d mee
Dromio, ſwore I was aſſur’d to her, told me what priuie
markes I had about mee, as the marke of my ſhoulder,
the Mole in my necke, the great Wart on my left arme,
that I amaz’d ranne from her as a witch. And I thinke, if
my breſt had not beene made of faith, and my heart of
ſteele, ſhe had transform’d me to a Curtull dog, & made
me turne i’th wheele.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Go hie thee preſently, poſt to the rode,
And if the winde blow any way from ſhore,
I will not harbour in this Towne to night.
If any Barke put forth, come to the Mart,
Where I will walke till thou returne to me:
If euerie one knowes vs, and we know none,
’Tis time I thinke to trudge, packe, and be gone.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: As from a Beare a man would run for life,
So flie I from her that would be my wife.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: There’s none but Witches do inhabite heere,
And therefore ’tis hie time that I were hence:
She that doth call me husband, euen my ſoule
Doth for a wife abhorre. But her faire ſiſter
Poſſeſt with ſuch a gentle ſoueraigne grace,
Of ſuch inchanting preſence and diſcourſe,
Hath almoſt made me Traitor to my ſelfe:
But leaſt my ſelfe be guilty to ſelfe wrong,
Ile ſtop mine eares againſt the Mermaids ſong.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Mr Antipholus.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: I that’s my name.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I know it well ſir, lœ here’s the chaine,
I thought to haue tane you at the Porpentine,
The chaine vnfiniſh’d made me ſtay thus long.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: What is your will that I ſhal do with this?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: What pleaſe your ſelfe ſir: I haue made it for
you.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Made it for me ſir, I beſpoke it not.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Not once, nor twice, but twentie times you
haue:
Go home with it, and pleaſe your Wife withall,
And ſoone at ſupper time Ile viſit you,
And then receiue my money for the chaine.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: I pray you ſir receiue the money now.
For feare you ne’re ſee chaine, nor mony more.

speech.speaker: Ang
speech.line: You are a merry man ſir, fare you well.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What I ſhould thinke of this, I cannot tell:
But this I thinke, there’s no man is ſo vaine,
That would refuſe ſo faire an offer’d Chaine.
I ſee a man heere needs not liue by ſhifts,
When in the ſtreets he meetes ſuch Golden gifts:
Ile to the Mart, and there for Dromio ſtay,
If any ſhip put out, then ſtraight away.

scene.stagedir: Enter a Merchant, Goldſmith, and an Officer.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You know ſince Pentecoſt the ſum is due,
And ſince I haue not much importun’d you,
Nor now I had not, but that I am bound
To Perſia, and want Gilders for my voyage:
Therefore make preſent ſatisfaƈtion,
Or Ile attach you by this Officer.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Euen iuſt the ſum that I do owe to you,
Is growing to me by Antipholus,
And in the inſtant that I met with you,
He had of me a Chaine, at fiue a clocke
I ſhall receiue the money for the ſame:
Pleaſeth you walke with me downe to his houſe,
I will diſcharge my bond, and thanke you too.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus Epheſ. Dromio from the Courtizans.

speech.speaker: Offi.
speech.line: That labour may you ſaue: See where he comes.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: While I go to the Goldſmiths houſe, go thou
And buy a ropes end, that will I beſtow
Among my wife, and their confederates,
For locking me out of my doores by day:
But ſoft I ſee the Goldſmith; get thee gone,
Buy thou a rope, and bring it home to me.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: I buy a thouſand pound a yeare, I buy a rope.

speech.speaker: Eph.Ant.
speech.line: A man is well holpe vp that truſts to you,
I promiſed your preſence, and the Chaine,
But neither Chaine nor Goldſmith came to me:
Belike you thought our loue would laſt too long
If it were chain’d together: and therefore came not.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Sauing your merrie humor: here’s the note
How much your Chaine weighs to the vtmoſt chareƈt,
The fineneſſe of the Gold, and chargefull faſhion,
Which doth amount to three odde Duckets more
Then I ſtand debted to this Gentleman,
I pray you ſee him presently diſcharg’d,
For he is bound to Sea, and ſtayes but for it.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: I am not furniſh’d with the present monie:
Beſides I haue ſome buſineſſe in the towne,
Good Signior take the ſtranger to my houſe,
And with you take the Chaine, and bid my wife
Disburſe the ſumme, on the receit thereof,
Perchance I will be there as ſoone as you.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Then you will bring the Chaine to her your
ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: No beare it with you, leaſt I come not time e-
nough.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Well ſir, I will? Haue you the Chaine about
you?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And if I haue not ſir, I hope you haue:
Or elſe you may returne without your money.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Nay come I pray you ſir, giue me the Chaine:
Both winde and tide ſtayes for this Gentleman,
And I too blame haue held him heere too long.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Good Lord, you vſe this dalliance to excuſe
Your breach of promiſe to the Porpentine,
I ſhould haue chid you for not bringing it,
But like a ſhrew you firſt begin to brawle.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: The houre ſteales on, I pray you ſir diſpatch.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: You heare how he importunes me, the Chaine.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why giue it to my wife, and fetch your mony.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Come, come, you know I gaue it you euen now.
Either ſend the Chaine, or ſend me by ſome token.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fie, now you run this humor out of breath,
Come where’s the Chaine, I pray you let me ſee it.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My buſineſſe cannot brooke this dalliance,
Good ſir ſay, whe’r you’l anſwer me, or no:
If not, Ile leaue him to the Officer.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I anſwer you? What ſhould I anſwer you.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: The monie that you owe me for the Chaine.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I owe you none, till I receiue the Chaine.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: You know I gaue it you halfe an houre ſince.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: You gaue me none, you wrong mee much to
ſay ſo.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: You wrong me more ſir in denying it.
Conſider how it ſtands vpon my credit.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Well Officer, arreſt him at my ſuite.

speech.speaker: Offi.
speech.line: I do, and charge you in the Dukes name to o-
bey me.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: This touches me in reputation.
Either conſent to pay this ſum for me,
Or I attach you by this Officer.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Conſent to pay thee that I neuer had:
Arreſt me fooliſh fellow if thou dar’ſt.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Heere is thy fee, arreſt him Officer.
I would not ſpare my brother in this caſe,
If he ſhould ſcorne me ſo apparantly.

speech.speaker: Offic.
speech.line: I do arreſt you ſir, you heare the ſuite.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I do obey thee, till I giue thee baile.
But ſirrah, you ſhall buy this ſport as deere,
As all the mettall in your ſhop will anſwer.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Sir, ſir, I ſhall haue Law in Epheſus,
To your notorious ſhame, I doubt it not.

scene.stagedir: Enter Dromio Sira. from the Bay.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Maſter, there’s a Barke of Epidamium,
That ſtaies but till her Owner comes aboord,
And then ſir ſhe beares away. Our fraughtage ſir,
I haue conuei’d aboord, and I haue bought
The Oyle, the Balſamum, and Aqua-vitæ.
The ſhip is in her trim, the merrie winde
Blowes faire from land: they ſtay for nought at all,
But for their Owner, Maſter, and your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: How now? a Madman? Why thou peeuiſh ſheep
What ſhip of Epidamium ſtaies for me.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: A ſhip you ſent me too, to hier waſtage.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thou drunken ſlaue, I ſent thee for a rope,
And told thee to what purpoſe, and what end.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: You ſent me for a ropes end as ſoone,
You ſent me to the Bay ſir, for a Barke.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I will debate this matter at more leiſure
And teach your eares to liſt me with more heede:
To Adriana Villaine hie thee ſtraight:
Giue her this key, and tell her in the Deske
That’s couer’d o’re with Turkiſh Tapiſtrie,
There is a purſe of Duckets, let her ſend it:
Tell her, I am arreſted in the ſtreete,
And that ſhall baile me: hie thee ſlaue, be gone,
On Officer to priſon, till it come.

speech.speaker: S.Dromio.
speech.line: To Adriana, that is where we din’d,
Where Dowſabell did claime me for her husband,
She is too bigge I hope for me to compaſſe,
Thither I muſt, although againſt my will:
For ſeruants muſt their Maſters mindes fulfill.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Ah Luciana, did he tempt thee ſo?
Might’ſt thou perceiue auſteerely in his eie,
That he did plead in earneſt, yea or no:
Look’d he or red or pale, or ſad or merrily?
What obſeruation mad’ſt thou in this caſe?
Oh, his hearts Meteors tilting in his face.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Firſt he deni’de you had in him no right.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: He meant he did me none: the more my ſpight

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Then ſwore he that he was a ſtranger heere.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: And true he ſwore, though yet forſworne hee
were.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Then pleaded I for you.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: And what ſaid he?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: That loue I begg’d for you, he begg’d of me.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: With what perſwaſion did he tempt thy loue?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: With words, that in an honeſt ſuit might moue.
Firſt, he did praiſe my beautie, then my ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Did’ſt ſpeake him faire?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Haue patience I beſeech.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I cannot, nor I will not hold me ſtill.
My tongue, though not my heart, ſhall haue his will.
He is deformed, crooked, old, and ſere,
Ill-fac’d, worſe bodied, ſhapeleſſe euery where:
Vicious, vngentle, fooliſh, blunt, vnkinde,
Stigmaticall in making worſe in minde.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Who would be iealous then of ſuch a one?
No euill loſt is wail’d, when it is gone.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Ah but I thinke him better then I ſay:
And yet would herein others eies were worſe:
Farre from her neſt the Lapwing cries away;
My heart praies for him, though my tongue dœ curſe.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Here gœ: the deske, the purſe, ſweet now make
haſte.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: How haſt thou loſt thy breath?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: By running faſt.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Where is thy Maſter Dromio? Is he well?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: No, he’s in Tartar limbo, worſe then hell:
A diuell in an euerlaſting garment hath him;
On whoſe hard heart is button’d vp with ſteele:
A Feind, a Fairie, pittileſſe and ruffe:
A Wolfe, nay worſe, a fellow all in buffe:
A back friend, a ſhoulder-clapper, one that countermáds
The paſſages of allies, creekes, and narrow lands:
A hound that runs Counter, and yet draws drifoot well,
One that before the Iudgmēt carries poore ſoules to hel.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Why man, what is the matter?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I dœ not know the matter, hee is reſted on
the caſe.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: What is he arreſted? tell me at whoſe ſuite?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I know not at whoſe ſuite he is areſted well;
but is in a ſuite of buffe which reſted him, that can I tell,
will you ſend him Miſtris redemption, the monie in
his deske.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Go fetch it Siſter: this I wonder at.
Thus he vnknowne to me ſhould be in debt:
Tell me, was he areſted on a band?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Not on a band, but on a ſtronger thing:
A chaine, a chaine, dœ you not here it ring.

speech.speaker: Adria.
speech.line: What, the chaine?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: No, no, the bell, ’tis time that I were gone:
It was two ere I left him, and now the clocke ſtrikes one.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: The houres come backe, that did I neuer here.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Oh yes, if any houre meete a Serieant, a turnes
backe for verie feare.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: As if time were in debt: how fondly do’ſt thou
reaſon?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Time is a verie bankerout, and owes more then
he’s worth to ſeaſon.
Nay, he’s a theefe too: haue you not heard men ſay,
That time comes ſtealing on by night and day?
If I be in debt and theft, and a Serieant in the way,
Hath he not reaſon to turne backe an houre in a day?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Go Dromio, there’s the monie, beare it ſtraight,
And bring thy Maſter home imediately.
Come ſiſter, I am preſt downe with conceit:
Conceit, my comfort and my iniurie.
There’s not a man I meete but doth ſalute me
As if I were their well acquainted friend,
And euerie one doth call me by my name:
Some tender monie to me, ſome inuite me;
Some other giue me thankes for kindneſſes;
Some offer me Commodities to buy.
Euen now a tailor cal’d me in his ſhop,
And ſhow’d me Silkes that he had bought for me,
And therewithall tooke meaſure of my body.
Sure theſe are but imaginarie wiles,
And lapland Sorcerers inhabite here.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Maſter, here’s the gold you ſent me for what
haue you got the piƈture of old Adam new apparel’d?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What gold is this? What Adam do’ſt thou
meane?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Not that Adam that kept the Paradiſe: but
that Adam that keepes the priſon; hee that goes in the
calues-skin, that was kil’d for the Prodigall: hee that
came behinde you ſir, like an euill angel, and bid you for-
ſake your libertie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I vnderſtand thee not.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: No? why ’tis a plaine caſe: he that went like
a Baſe-Viole in a caſe of leather; the man ſir, that when
gentlemen are tired giues them a ſob, and reſts them:
he ſir, that takes pittie on decaied men, and giues them
ſuites of durance: he that ſets vp his reſt to dœ more ex-
ploits with his Mace, then a Moris Pike.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What thou mean’ſt an officer?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: I ſir, the Serieant of the Band: he that brings
any man to anſwer it that breakes his Band: one that
thinkes a man alwaies going to bed, and ſaies, God giue
you good reſt.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Well ſir, there reſt in your foolerie:
Is there any ſhips puts forth to night? may we be gone?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Why ſir, I brought you word an houre ſince,
that the Barke Expedition put forth to night, and then
were you hindred by the Serieant to tarry for the Hoy
Delay: Here are the angels that you ſent for to deliuer
you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The fellow is distraƈt, and ſo am I,
And here we wander in illuſions:
Some bleſſed power deliuer vs from hence.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Well met, well met, Maſter Antipholus:
I ſee ſir you haue found the Gold-ſmith now:
Is that the chaine you promis’d me to day.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Sathan auoide, I charge thee tempt me not.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Maſter, is this Miſtris Sathan?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: It is the diuell.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Nay, ſhe is worſe, ſhe is the diuels dam:
And here ſhe comes in the habit of a light wench, and
thereof comes, that the wenches ſay God dam me, That’s
as much to ſay, God make me a light wench: It is writ-
ten, they appeare to men like angels of light, light is an
effeƈt of fire, and fire will burne: ergo, light wenches will
burne, come not neere her.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Your man and you are maruailous merrie ſir.
Will you gœ with me, wee’ll mend our dinner here?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Maſter, if do expeƈt ſpoon-meate, or beſpeake
a long ſpoone.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Why Dromio?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Marrie he muſt haue a long ſpoone that muſt
eate with the diuell.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Auoid then fiend, what tel’ſt thou me of ſupping?
Thou art, as you are all a ſorcereſſe:
I coniure thee to leaue me, and be gon.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Giue me the ring of mine you had at dinner,
Or for my Diamond the Chaine you promis’d,
And Ile be gone ſir, and not trouble you.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Some diuels aske but the parings of ones naile,
a ruſh, a haire, a drop of blood, a pin, a nut, a cherrie-
ſtone: but ſhe more couetous, wold haue a chaine: Ma-
ſter be wiſe, and if you giue it her, the diuell will ſhake
her Chaine, and fright vs with it.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: I pray you ſir my Ring, or elſe the Chaine,
I hope you do not meane to cheate me ſo?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Auant thou witch: Come Dromio let vs go.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Flie pride ſaies the Pea-cocke, Miſtris that
you know.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Now out of doubt Antipholus is mad,
Elſe would he neuer ſo demeane himſelfe,
A Ring he hath of mine worth fortie Duckets,
And for the ſame he promis’d me a Chaine,
Both one and other he denies me now:
The reaſon that I gather he is mad,
Beſides this preſent inſtance of his rage,
Is a mad tale he told to day at dinner,
Of his owne doores being ſhut againſt his entrance.
Belike his wife acquainted with his fits,
On purpoſe ſhut the doores againſt his way:
My way is now to hie home to his houſe,
And tell his wife, that being Lunaticke,
He ruſh’d into my houſe, and tooke perforce
My Ring away. This courſe I fitteſt chooſe,
For fortie Duckets is too much to looſe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus Epheſ. with a Iailor.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: Feare me not man, I will not breake away,
Ile giue thee ere I leaue thee ſo much money
To warrant thee as I am reſted for.
My wife is in a wayward moode to day,
And will not lightly truſt the Meſſenger,
That I ſhould be attach’d in Epheſus,
I tell you ’twill ſound harſhly in her eares.
speech.stagedir: Enter Dromio Eph. with a ropes end.
speech.line: Heere comes my Man, I thinke he brings the monie.
How now ſir? Haue you that I ſent you for?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Here’s that I warrant you will pay them all.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: But where’s the Money?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Why ſir, I gaue the Monie for the Rope.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Fiue hundred Duckets villaine for a rope?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Ile ſerue you ſir fiue hundred at the rate.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: To what end did I bid thee hie thee home?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: To a ropes end ſir, and to that end am I re-
turn’d.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And to that end ſir, I will welcome you.

speech.speaker: Offi.
speech.line: Good ſir be patient.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Nay ’tis for me to be patient, I am in aduer-
ſitie.

speech.speaker: Offi.
speech.line: Good now hold thy tongue.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Nay, rather perſwade him to hold his hands.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Thou whoreſon ſenseleſſe Villaine.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: I would I were ſenseleſſe ſir, that I might
not feele your blowes.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Thou art ſensible in nothing but blowes, and
ſo is an Aſſe.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: I am an Aſſe indeede, you may prooue it by
my long eares. I haue ſerued him from the houre of my
Natiuitie to this inſtant, and haue nothing at his hands
for my ſeruice but blowes. When I am cold, he heates
me with beating: when I am warme, he cooles me with
beating: I am wak’d with it when I ſleepe, rais’d with
it when I ſit, driuen out of doores with it when I gœ
from home, welcom’d home with it when I returne, nay
I beare it on my ſhoulders, as a begger woont her brat:
and I thinke when he hath lam’d me, I ſhall begge with
it from doore to doore.

scene.stagedir: Enter Adriana, Luciana, Courtizan, and a Schoole- maſter, call’d Pinch.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come gœ along, my wife is comming yon-
der.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Miſtris reſpice finem, reſpeƈt your end, or ra-
ther the propheſie like the Parrat, beware the ropes end.

speech.speaker: Anti
speech.line: Wilt thou ſtill talke?

speech.speaker: Curt.
speech.line: How ſay you now? Is not your husband mad?

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: His inciuility confirmes no leſſe:
Good Doƈtor Pinch, you are a Coniurer,
Eſtabliſh him in his true ſence againe,
And I will pleaſe you what you will demand.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Alas how fiery, and how ſharpe he lookes.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Marke, how he trembles in his extaſie.

speech.speaker: Pinch.
speech.line: Giue me your hand, and let mee feele your
pulſe.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: There is my hand, and let it feele your eare.

speech.speaker: Pinch.
speech.line: I charge thee Sathan, hous’d within this man,
To yeeld poſſeſſion to my holie praiers,
And to thy ſtate of darkneſſe hie thee ſtraight,
I coniure thee by all the Saints in heauen.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Peace doting wizard, peace; I am not mad.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Oh that thou wer’t not, poore distreſſed ſoule.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: You Minion you, are theſe your Cuſtomers?
Did this Companion with the ſaffron face
Reuell and feaſt it at my houſe to day,
Whil’ſt vpon me the guiltie doores were ſhut,
And I denied to enter in my houſe.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: O husband, God doth know you din’d at home
Where would you had remain’d vntill this time,
Free from theſe ſlanders, and this open ſhame.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Din’d at home? Thou Villaine, what ſayeſt
thou?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Sir ſooth to ſay, you did not dine at home.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Were not my doores lockt vp, and I ſhut out?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Perdie, your doores were lockt, and you ſhut
out.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: And did not ſhe her ſelfe reuile me there?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Sans Fable, ſhe her ſelfe reuil’d you there.

speech.speaker: Anti.
speech.line: Did not her Kitchen maide raile, taunt, and
ſcorne me?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Certis ſhe did, the kitchin veſtall ſcorn’d you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: And did not I in rage depart from thence?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: In veritie you did, my bones beares witneſſe,
That ſince haue felt the vigor of his rage.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Is’t good to ſooth him in theſe contraries?

speech.speaker: Pinch.
speech.line: It is no ſhame, the fellow finds his vaine,
And yeelding to him, humors well his frenſie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thou haſt ſubborn’d the Goldſmith to arreſt
mee.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Alas, I ſent you Monie to redeeme you,
By Dromio heere, who came in haſt for it.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Monie by me? Heart and good will you might,
But ſurely Maſter not a ragge of Monie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Wentſt not thou to her for a purſe of Duckets.

speech.speaker: Adri.
speech.line: He came to me, and I deliuer’d it.

speech.speaker: Luci.
speech.line: And I am witneſſe with her that ſhe did:

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: God and the Rope-maker beare me witneſſe,
That I was ſent for nothing but a rope.

speech.speaker: Pinch.
speech.line: Miſtris, both Man and Maſter is poſſeſt,
I know it by their pale and deadly lookes,
They muſt be bound and laide in ſome darke roome.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Say wherefore didſt thou locke me forth to day,
And why doſt thou denie the bagge of gold?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I did not gentle husband locke thee forth.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: And gentle Mr I receiu’d no gold:
But I confeſſe ſir, that we were lock’d out.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Diſſembling Villain, thou ſpeak’ſt falſe in both

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Diſſembling harlot, thou art falſe in all,
And art confederate with a damned packe,
To make a loathſome abieƈt ſcorne of me:
But with theſe nailes, Ile plucke out theſe falſe eyes,
That would behold in me this ſhamefull ſport.

scene.stagedir: Enter three or foure, and offer to binde him:

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Oh binde him, binde him, let him not come
neere me.

speech.speaker: Pinch.
speech.line: More company, the fiend is ſtrong within him

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Aye me poore man, how pale and wan he looks.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: What will you murther me, thou Iailor thou?
I am thy priſoner, wilt thou ſuffer them to make a reſ-
cue?

speech.speaker: Offi.
speech.line: Maſters let him go: he is my priſoner, and you
ſhall not haue him.

speech.speaker: Pinch.
speech.line: Go binde this man, for he is franticke too.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: What wilt thou do, thou peeuiſh Officer?
Haſt thou delight to ſee a wretched man
Do outrage and diſpleaſure to himſelfe?

speech.speaker: Offi.
speech.line: He is my priſoner, if I let him go,
The debt he owes will be requir’d of me.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I will diſcharge thee ere I go from thee,
Beare me forthwith vnto his Creditor,
And knowing how the debt growes I will pay it.
Good Maſter Doƈtor ſee him ſafe conuey’d
Home to my houſe, oh mo’t vnhappy day.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Oh moſt vnhappie ſtrumpet.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Maſter, I am heere entred in bond for you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Out on thee Villaine, wherefore doſt thou mad
mee?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Will you be bound for nothing, be mad good
Maſter, cry the diuell.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: God helpe poore ſoules, how idlely dœ they
talke.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Go beare him hence, ſiſter go you with me:
Say now, whoſe ſuite is he arreſted at?

scene.stagedir: Exeunt. Manet Offic. Adri. Luci. Courtizan

speech.speaker: Off.
speech.line: One Angelo a Goldſmith, do you know him?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I know the man: what is the ſumme he owes?

speech.speaker: Off.
speech.line: Two hundred Duckets.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Say, how growes it due.

speech.speaker: Off.
speech.line: Due for a Chaine your husband had of him.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: He did beſpeake a Chain for me, but had it not.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: When as your husband all in rage to day
Came to my houſe, and tooke away my Ring,
The Ring I ſaw vpon his finger now,
Straight after did I meete him with a Chaine.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: It may be ſo, but I did neuer ſee it.
Come Iailor, bring me where the Goldſmith is,
I long to know the truth heereof at large.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus Siracuſia with his Rapier drawne, and Dromio Sirac.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: God for thy mercy, they are looſe againe.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: And come with naked ſwords,
Let’s call more helpe to haue them bound againe.

speech.speaker: Off.
speech.line: Away, they’l kill vs.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt omnes, as faſt as may be, frighted.

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: I ſee theſe Witches are affraid of ſwords.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: She that would be your wife, now ran from
you.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Come to the Centaur, fetch our ſtuffe from
thence:
I long that we were ſafe and ſound aboord.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Faith ſtay heere this night, they will ſurely do
vs no harme: you ſaw they ſpeake vs faire, giue vs gold:
me thinkes they are ſuch a gentle Nation, that but for
the Mountaine of mad fleſh that claimes mariage of me,
I could finde in my heart to ſtay heere ſtill, and turne
Witch.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I will not ſtay to night for all the Towne,
Therefore away, to get our ſtuffe aboord.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Merchant and the Goldſmith.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: I am ſorry Sir that I haue hindred you,
But I proteſt he had the Chaine of me,
Though moſt diſhoneſtly he doth denie it.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: How is the man eſteem’d heere in the Citie?

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Of very reuerent reputation ſir,
Of credit infinite, highly belou’d,
Second to none that liues heere in the Citie:
His word might beare my wealth at any time.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Speake ſoftly, yonder as I thinke he walkes.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: ’Tis ſo: and that ſelfe chaine about his necke,
Which he forſwore moſt monſtrouſly to haue.
Good ſir draw neere to me, Ile ſpeake to him:
Signior Antipholus, I wonder much
That you would put me to this ſhame and trouble,
And not without ſome ſcandall to your ſelfe,
With circumſtance and oaths, ſo to denie
This Chaine, which now you weare ſo openly.
Beſide the charge, the ſhame, impriſonment,
You haue done wrong to this my honeſt friend,
Who but for ſtaying on our Controuerſie,
Had hoiſted ſaile, and put to ſea to day:
This Chaine you had of me, can you deny it?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I thinke I had, I neuer did deny it.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Yes that you did ſir, and forſwore it too.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Who heard me to denie it or forſweare it?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Theſe eares of mine thou knowſt did hear thee:
Fie on thee wretch, ’tis pitty that thou liu’ſt
To walke where any honeſt men reſort.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Thou art a Villaine to impeach me thus,
Ile proue mine honor, and mine honeſtie
Againſt thee preſently, if thou dar’ſt ſtand:

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I dare and do defie thee for a villaine.

scene.stagedir: They draw. Enter Adriana, Luciana, Courtezan, & others.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Hold, hurt him not for God ſake, he is mad,
Some get within him, take his ſword away:
Binde Dromio too, and beare them to my houſe.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Runne maſter run, for Gods ſake take a houſe,
This is ſome Priorie, in, or we are ſpoyl’d.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: Be quiet people, wherefore throng you hither?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: To fetch my poore diſtraƈted husband hence,
Let vs come in, that we may binde him faſt,
And beare him home for his recouerie.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: I knew he was not in his perfeƈt wits.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I am ſorry now that I did draw on him.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: How long hath this poſſeſſion held the man.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: This weeke he hath beene heauie, ſower ſad,
And much different from the man he was:
But till this afternoone his paſſion
Ne’re brake into extremity of rage.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: Hath he not loſt much wealth by wrack of ſea,
Buried ſome deere friend, hath not elſe his eye
Stray’d his affeƈtion in vnlawfull loue,
A ſinne preuailing much in youthfull men,
Who giue their eies the liberty of gazing.
Which of theſe ſorrowes is he ſubieƈt too?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: To none of theſe, except it be the laſt,
Namely, ſome loue that drew him oft from home.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: You ſhould for that haue reprehended him.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Why ſo I did.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: I but not rough enough.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: As roughly as my modeſtie would let me.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: Haply in priuate.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: And in aſſemblies too.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: I, but not enough.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: It was the copie of our Conference.
In bed he ſlept not for my vrging it,
At boord he fed not for my vrging it:
Alone, it was the ſubieƈt of my Theame:
In company I often glanced it:
Still did I tell him, it was vilde and bad.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: And thereof came it, that the man was mad.
The venome clamors of a iealous woman,
Poiſons more deadly then a mad dogges tooth.
It ſeemes his ſleepes were hindred by thy railing,
And thereof comes it that his head is light.
Thou ſaiſt his meate was ſawc’d with thy vpbraidings,
Vnquiet meales make ill digeſtions,
Thereof the raging fire of feauer bred,
And what’s a Feauer, but a fit of madneſſe?
Thou ſayeſt his ſports were hindred by thy bralles.
Sweet recreation barr’d, what doth enſue
But moodie and dull melancholly,
Kinſman to grim and comfortleſſe diſpaire,
And at her heeles a huge infeƈtious troope
Of pale diſtemperatures, and fœs to life?
In food, in ſport, and life-preſeruing reſt
To be diſturb’d, would mad or man, or beaſt:
The conſequence is then, thy iealous fits
Hath ſcar’d thy husband from the vſe of wits.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: She neuer reprehended him but mildely,
When he demean’d himſelfe, rough, rude, and wildly,
Why beare you theſe rebukes, and anſwer not?

speech.speaker: Adri.
