speech.line: She did betray me to my owne reproofe,
Good people enter, and lay hold on him.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: No, not a creature enters in my houſe.

speech.speaker: Ad.
speech.line: Then let your ſeruants bring my husband forth

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: Neither: he tooke this place for ſanƈtuary,
And it ſhall priuiledge him from your hands,
Till I haue brought him to his wits againe,
Or looſe my labour in aſſaying it.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I will attend my husband, be his nurſe,
Diet his ſickneſſe, for it is my Office,
And will haue no atturney but my ſelfe,
And therefore let me haue him home with me.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: Be patient, for I will not let him ſtirre,
Till I haue vs’d the approoued meanes I haue,
With wholſome ſirrups, drugges, and holy prayers
To make of him a formall man againe:
It is a branch and parcell of mine oath,
A charitable dutie of my order,
Therefore depart, and leaue him heere with me.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I will not hence, and leaue my husband heere:
And ill it doth beſeeme your holineſſe
To ſeparate the husband and the wife.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: Be quiet and depart, thou ſhalt not haue him.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Complaine vnto the Duke of this indignity.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Come go, I will fall proſtrate at his feete,
And neuer riſe vntill my teares and prayers
Haue won his grace to come in perſon hither,
And take perforce my husband from the Abbeſſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: By this I thinke the Diall points at fiue:
Anon I’me ſure the Duke himſelfe in perſon
Comes this way to the melancholly vale;
The place of depth, and ſorrie execution,
Behinde the ditches of the Abbey heere.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: Vpon what cauſe?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: To ſee a reuerent Siracuſian Merchant,
Who put vnluckily into this Bay
Againſt the Lawes and Statutes of this Towne,
Beheaded publikely for his offence.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: See where they come, we wil behold his death

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Kneele to the Duke before he paſſe the Abbey.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Duke of Epheſus, and the Merchant of Siracuſe bare head, with the Headſman, & other Officers

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Yet once againe proclaime it publikely,
If any friend will pay the ſumme for him,
He ſhall not die, ſo much we tender him.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Iuſtice moſt ſacred Duke against the Abbeſſe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: She is a vertuous and a reuerend Lady,
It cannot be that ſhe hath done thee wrong.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: May it pleaſe your Grace, Antipholus my husbád,
Who I made Lord of me, and all I had,
At your important Letters this ill day,
A moſt outragious fit of madneſſe tooke him:
That deſp’rately he hurried through the ſtreete,
With him his bondman, all as mad as he,
Doing diſpleaſure to the Citizens,
By ruſhing in their houſes: bearing thence
Rings, Iewels, any thing his rage did like.
Once did I get him bound, and ſent him home,
Whil’ſt to take order for the wrongs I went,
That heere and there his furie had committed,
Anon I wot not, by what ſtrong eſcape
He broke from thoſe that had the guard of him,
And with his mad attendant and himſelfe,
Each one with irefull paſſion, with drawne ſwords
Met vs againe, and madly bent on vs
Chac’d vs away: till raiſing of more aide
We came againe to binde them: then they fled
Into this Abbey, whether we purſu’d them,
And heere the Abbeſſe ſhuts the gates on vs,
And will not ſuffer vs to fetch him out,
Nor ſend him forth, that we may beare him hence.
Therefore moſt gracious Duke with thy command,
Let him be brought forth, and borne hence for helpe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Long ſince thy husband ſeru’d me in my wars
And I to thee ingag’d a Princes word,
When thou didſt make him Maſter of thy bed,
To do him all the grace and good I could.
Go ſome of you, knocke at the Abbey gate,
And bid the Lady Abbeſſe come to me:
I will determine this before I ſtirre.
Oh Miſtris, Miſtris, ſhift and ſaue your ſelfe,
My Maſter and his man are both broke looſe,
Beaten the Maids a-row, and bound the Doƈtor,
Whoſe beard they haue ſindg’d off with brands of fire,
And euer as it blaz’d, they threw on him
Great pailes of puddled myre to quench the haire;
My Mr preaches patience to him, and the while
His man with Cizers nickes him like a foole:
And ſure (vnleſſe you ſend ſome present helpe)
Betweene them they will kill the Coniurer.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Peace foole, thy Maſter and his man are here,
And that is falſe thou doſt report to vs.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Miſtris, vpon my life I tel you true,
I haue not breath’d almoſt ſince I did ſee it.
He cries for you, and vowes if he can take you,
To ſcorch your face, and to disfigure you:
Harke, harke, I heare him Miſtris: flie, be gone.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Come ſtand by me, feare nothing: guard with
Halberds.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Ay me, it is my husband: witneſſe you,
That he is borne about inuiſible,
Euen now we hous’d him in the Abbey heere.
And now he’s there, paſt thought of humane reaſon.

scene.stagedir: Enter Antipholus, and E. Dromio of Epheſus.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: Iustice moſt gracious Duke, oh grant me iustice,
Euen for the ſeruice that long ſince I did thee,
When I beſtrid thee in the warres, and tooke
Deepe ſcarres to ſaue thy life; euen for the blood
That then I loſt for thee, now grant me iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Mar.Fat.
speech.line: Vnleſſe the feare of death doth make me
dote, I ſee my ſonne Antipholus and Dromio.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: Iuſtice (ſweet Prince) againſt ý Woman there:
She whom thou gau’ſt to me to be my wife;
That hath abuſed and diſhonored me,
Euen in the ſtrength and height of iniurie:
Beyond imagination is the wrong
That ſhe this day hath ſhameleſſe throwne on me.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Diſcouer how, and thou ſhalt finde me iuſt.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: This day (great Duke) ſhe ſhut the doores
vpon me,
While ſhe with Harlots feaſted in my houſe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: A greeuous fault: ſay woman, didſt thou ſo?

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: No my good Lord. My ſelfe, he, and my ſiſter,
To day did dine together: ſo befall my ſoule,
As this is falſe he burthens me withall.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Nere may I looke on day, nor ſleepe on night,
But ſhe tels to your Highneſſe ſimple truth.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: O periur’d woman! They are both forſworne,
In this the Madman iuſtly chargeth them.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: My Liege, I am aduiſed what I ſay,
Neither diſturbed with the effeƈt of Wine,
Nor headie-raſh prouoak’d with raging ire,
Albeit my wrongs might make one wiſer mad.
This woman lock’d me out this day from dinner;
That Goldſmith there, were he not pack’d with her,
Could witneſſe it: for he was with me then,
Who parted with me to go fetch a Chaine,
Promiſing to bring it to the Porpentine,
Where Balthaſar and I did dine together.
Our dinner done, and he not comming thither,
I went to ſeeke him. In the ſtreet I met him,
And in his companie that Gentleman.
There did this periur’d Goldſmith ſweare me downe,
That I this day of him receiu’d the Chaine,
Which God he knowes, I ſaw not. For the which,
He did arreſt me with an Officer.
I did obey, and ſent my Peſant home
For certaine Duckets: he with none return’d.
Then fairely I beſpoke the Officer
To go in perſon with me to my houſe.
By th’ way, we met my wife, her ſiſter, and a rabble more
Of vilde Confederates: Along with them
They brought one Pinch, a hungry leane-fac’d Villaine;
A meere Anatomie, a Mountebanke,
A thred-bare Iugler, and a Fortune-teller,
A needy-hollow-ey’d-ſharpe-looking-wretch;
A liuing dead man. This pernicious ſlaue,
Forſooth tooke on him as a Coniurer:
And gazing in mine eyes, feeling my pulſe,
And with no-face (as ’twere) out-facing me,
Cries out, I was poſſeſt. Then altogether
They fell vpon me, bound me, bore me thence,
And in a darke and dankiſh vault at home
There left me and my man, both bound together,
Till gnawing with my teeth my bonds in ſunder,
I gain’d my freedome; and immediately
Ran hether to your Grace, whom I beſeech
To giue me ample ſatisfaƈtion
For theſe deepe ſhames, and great indignities.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: My Lord, in truth, thus far I witnes with him:
That he din’d not at home, but was lock’d out.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: But had he ſuch a Chaine of thee, or no?

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: He had my Lord, and when he ran in heere,
Theſe people ſaw the Chaine about his necke.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Beſides, I will be ſworne theſe eares of mine,
Heard you confeſſe you had the Chaine of him,
After you firſt forſwore it on the Mart,
And thereupon I drew my ſword on you:
And then you fled into this Abbey heere,
From whence I thinke you are come by Miracle.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: I neuer came within theſe Abbey wals,
Nor euer didſt thou draw thy ſword on me:
I neuer ſaw the Chaine, ſo helpe me heauen:
And this is falſe you burthen me withall.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why what an intricate impeach is this?
I thinke you all haue drunke of Circes cup:
If heere you hous’d him, heere he would haue bin.
If he were mad, he would not pleade ſo coldly:
You ſay he din’d at home, the Goldſmith heere
Denies that ſaying. Sirra, what ſay you?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Sir he din’de with her there, at the Porpen-
tine.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: He did, and from my finger ſnacht that Ring.

speech.speaker: E.Anti.
speech.line: Tis true (my Liege) this Ring I had of her.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Saw’ſt thou him enter at the Abbey heere?

speech.speaker: Curt.
speech.line: As ſure (my Liege) as I do ſee your Grace.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why this is ſtraunge: Go call the Abbeſſe hi-
ther.
I thinke you are all mated, or ſtarke mad.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Mo’t mighty Duke, vouchſafe me ſpeak a word:
Haply I ſee a friend will ſaue my life,
And pay the ſum that may deliuer me.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Speake freely Siracuſian what thou wilt.

speech.speaker: Fath.
speech.line: Is not your name ſir call’d Antipholus?
And is not that your bondman Dromio?

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Within this houre I was his bondman ſir,
But he I thanke him gnaw’d in two my cords,
Now am I Dromio, and his man, vnbound.

speech.speaker: Fath.
speech.line: I am ſure you both of you remember me.

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: Our ſelues we do remember ſir by you:
For lately we were bound as you are now.
You are not Pinches patient, are you ſir?

speech.speaker: Father.
speech.line: Why looke you ſtrange on me? you know
me well.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: I neuer ſaw you in my life till now.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Oh! griefe hath chang’d me ſince you ſaw me laſt,
And carefull houres with times deformed hand,
Haue written ſtrange defeatures in my face:
But tell me yet, doſt thou not know my voice?

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: Neither.

speech.speaker: Fat.
speech.line: Dromio, nor thou?

speech.speaker: Dro.
speech.line: No truſt me ſir, nor I.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: I am ſure thou doſt?

speech.speaker: E.Dromio.
speech.line: I ſir, but I am ſure I do not, and whatſo-
euer a man denies, you are now bound to beleeue him.

speech.speaker: Fath.
speech.line: Not know my voice, oh times etremity
Haſt thou ſo crack’d and ſplitted my poore tongue
In ſeuen ſhort yeares, that heere my onely ſonne
Knowes not my feeble key of vntun’d cares?
Though now this grained face of mine be hid
In ſap-conſuming Winters drizled ſnow,
And all the Conduits of my blood froze vp:
Yet hath my night of life ſome memorie:
My waſting lampes ſome fading glimmer left;
My dull deafe eares a little vſe to heare:
All theſe old witneſſes, I cannot erre.
Tell me, thou art my ſonne Antipholus.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: I neuer ſaw my Father in my life.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: But ſeuen yeares ſince, in Siracuſa boy
Thou know’ſt we parted, but perhaps my ſonne,
Thou ſham’ſt to acknowledge me in miſerie.

speech.speaker: Ant.
speech.line: The Duke, and all that know me in the City,
Can witneſſe with me that it is not ſo.
I ne’re ſaw Siracuſa in my life.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I tell thee Siracuſian, twentie yeares
Haue I bin Patron to Antipholus,
During which time, he ne’re ſaw Siracuſa:
I ſee thy age and dangers make thee dote.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Abbeſſe with Antipholus Siracuſa, and Dromio Sir

speech.speaker: Abbeſſe.
speech.line: Moſt mightie Duke, behold a man much
wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I ſee two husbands, or mine eyes deceiue me.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: One of theſe men is genius to the other:
And ſo of theſe, which is the naturall man,
And which the ſpirit? Who deciphers them?

speech.speaker: S.Dromio.
speech.line: I Sir am Dromio, command him away.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: I Sir am Dromio, pray let me ſtay.

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: Egeon art thou not? or elſe his ghoſt.

speech.speaker: S.Drom.
speech.line: Oh my olde Maſter, who hath bound him
heere?

speech.speaker: Abb.
speech.line: Who euer bound him, I will loſe his bonds,
And gaine a husband by his libertie:
Speake olde Egeon, if thou bee’ſt the man
That hadſt a wife once call’d Æmilia,
That bore thee at a burthen two faire ſonnes?
Oh if thou bee’ſt the ſame Egeon, ſpeake:
And ſpeake vnto the ſame Æmilia.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why heere begins his Morning ſtorie right:
Theſe two Antipholus, theſe two ſo like,
And theſe two Dromio’s, one in ſemblance:
Beſides her vrging of her wracke at ſea,
Theſe are the parents to theſe children,
Which accidentally are met together.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: If I dreame not, thou art Æmilia,
If thou art ſhe, tell me, where is that ſonne
That floated with thee on the fatall rafte.

speech.speaker: Abb.
speech.line: By men of Epidamium, he, and I,
And the twin Dromio, all were taken vp;
But by and by, rude Fiſhermen of Corinth
By force tooke Dromio, and my ſonne from them,
And me they left with thoſe of Epidamium.
What then became of them, I cannot tell:
I, to this fortune that you ſee mee in.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Antipholus thou cam’ſt from Corinth firſt.

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: No ſir, not I, I came from Siracuſe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Stay, ſtand apart, I know not which is which.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: I came from Corinth my moſt gracious Lord

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: And I with him.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: Brought to this Town by that moſt famous
Warriour,
Duke Menaphon your moſt renowned Vnckle.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: Which of you two did dine with me to day?

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: I, gentle Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: And are not you my husband?

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: No, I ſay nay to that.

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: And ſo do I, yet did ſhe call me ſo:
And this faire Gentlewoman her ſiſter heere
Did call me brother. What I told you then,
I hope I ſhall haue leiſure to make good,
If this be not a dreame I ſee and heare.

speech.speaker: Goldſmith.
speech.line: That is the Chaine ſir, which you had of
mee.

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: I thinke it be ſir, I denie it not.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: And you ſir for this Chaine arreſted me.

speech.speaker: Gold.
speech.line: I thinke I did ſir, I deny it not.

speech.speaker: Adr.
speech.line: I ſent you monie ſir to be your baile
By Dromio, but I thinke he brought it not.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: No, none by me.

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: This purſe of Duckets I receiu’d from you,
And Dromio my man did bring them me:
I ſee we ſtill did meete each others man,
And I was tane for him, and he for me,
And thereupon theſe errors are aroſe.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: Theſe Duckets pawne I for my father heere.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: It ſhall not neede, thy father hath his life.

speech.speaker: Cur.
speech.line: Sir I muſt haue that Diamond from you.

speech.speaker: E.Ant.
speech.line: There take it, and much thanks for my good
cheere.

speech.speaker: Abb.
speech.line: Renowned Duke, vouchſafe to take the paines
To go with vs into the Abbey heere,
And heare at large diſcourſed all our fortunes,
And all that are aſſembled in this place:
That by this ſimpathized one daies error
Haue ſuffer’d wrong. Gœ keepe vs companie,
And we ſhall make full ſatisfaƈtion.
Thirtie three yeares haue I but gone in trauaile
Of you my ſonnes, and till this preſent houre
My heauie burthen are deliuered:
The Duke my husband, and my children both,
And you the Kalenders of their Natiuity,
Go to a Goſſips feaſt, and go with mee,
After ſo long greefe ſuch Natiuitie.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: With all my heart, Ile Goſſip at this feaſt.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt omnes. Manet the two Dromio’s and two Brothers.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Maſt. ſhall I fetch your ſtuffe from ſhipbord?

speech.speaker: E.An.
speech.line: Dromio, what ſtuffe of mine haſt thou imbarkt

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Your goods that lay at hoſt ſir in the Centaur.

speech.speaker: S.Ant.
speech.line: He ſpeakes to me, I am your maſter Dromio.
Come go with vs, wee’l looke to that anon,
Embrace thy brother there, reioyce with him.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: There is a fat friend at your maſters houſe,
That kitchin’d me for you to day at dinner:
She now ſhall be my ſiſter, not my wife,

speech.speaker: E.D.
speech.line: Me thinks you are my glaſſe, & not my brother:
I ſee by you, I am a ſweet-fac’d youth,
Will you walke in to ſee their goſſipping?

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Not I ſir, you are my elder.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: That’s a queſtion, how ſhall we trie it.

speech.speaker: S.Dro.
speech.line: Wee’l draw Cuts for the Signior, till then,
lead thou firſt.

speech.speaker: E.Dro.
speech.line: Nay then thus:
We came into the world like brother and brother:
And now let’s go hand in hand, not one before another.
